node.title: Satellite monitoring of emissions from countries and companies ‘changes everything,’ Al Gore says.
node.alt: Former Vice President Al Gore, speaking at the Climate Hub, a New York Times event series taking place alongside the COP26 Climate Conference in Glasgow, Scotland, on Wednesday.
node.description: Real-time checks on where greenhouse gases are being produced may prove a powerful weapon in the fight to cool the earth.
node.content: ["One of the challenges in holding companies and countries accountable for their roles in global warming is how greenhouse gas emission data has been self-reported, former Vice President Al Gore said Wednesday on the sidelines of the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow.", "\u201cThere\u2019s an old clich\u00e9 that I\u2019m sure you\u2019ve heard a million times: that you can only manage what you can measure,\u201d Mr. Gore said, speaking at the Climate Hub, a Times event series running alongside the conference. ", "But, he said, advances in satellite and computer analysis have enabled information about emissions to be tracked independently and in real time, helping scientists assign responsibility for emissions to specific industries, companies and regions.", "\u201cThat changes everything,\u201d he said.", "Mr. Gore\u2019s Climate Trace coalition, which began last year, issued its first report on greenhouse gas emissions in September. It was the culmination of a study that analyzed data from more than 300 satellites.", "\u201cWe now have the emissions, for the last five years, for every large source of greenhouse gas emissions on the planet,\u201d said Mr. Gore, whose film about climate change, \u201cAn Inconvenient Truth,\u201d won the 2007 Academy Award for best documentary. \u201cBy next year, we will have that down to such a granular level that we will be able to report monthly, weekly and in a few cases daily totals from every single significant machine source everywhere in the world.\u201d", "Mr. Gore said he wanted to focus on the potential for new technology to help make greenhouse gas emission reporting more transparent, more timely and more accurate. At past climate conferences, he said, the discussion was based on outdated data. There are 100 countries that don\u2019t have any emissions data that is more recent than five or even 20 years old, he said."]
